awd_titl_txt: Asymptotic Regimes of Nonlinear Dispersive Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The main objective of this project is to explore factors that vitally influence the long-time behavior of nonlinear dispersive PDE like the non-linear Schroedinger (NLS), nonlinear wave (NLW), nonlinear Klein-Gordon (NKG), and Zakharov systems. First, the effect of domain geometry is investigated in terms of a relation between the volume growth of the underlying manifold and the decay of linear solutions. The implications of this relation for the nonlinear problem are then explored in certain tractable geometries, namely quotients of Euclidean spaces. Second, the question of small-data scattering (asymptotically linear behavior) for some weakly nonlinear dispersive equations is considered. These are equations where the nonlinearity is not of high enough degree for classical methods to succeed. One focus is on inhomogeneities represented by a potential term, and how this can affect the asymptotic behavior. Finally, the so-called weakly turbulent regime is investigated by studying the long-time behavior of the cubic NLS equation on a compact domain. In this context, a new continuum equation is derived for the envelope of the discrete Fourier modes by taking a suitable large-box limit in the spirit of weak turbulence theory. This equation turns out to enjoy remarkable symmetries and even explicit solutions, and can be used (via rigorous approximation results) to better understand the long-time frequency dynamics of the original NLS system.

The nonlinear dispersive equations considered in this project arise naturally in several areas of physics (plasma physics, nonlinear optics, general relativity, etc.) where they often serve as simplified effective models. In order for these models to be useful for engineering purposes as well, one has to understand the effect of inhomogeneities (usually modeled by a non-Euclidean domain geometry or a potential term) in making connections with the real world. Such a study would help set the parameters and limitations of not only the validity of the existing simplified models, but also the faithfulness of computer simulations (based on those models) in predicting experimental phenomena. On a more theoretical note, starting a mathematically rigorous study of the all-important physical theory of weak turbulence, as suggested in the proposal, represents a cross-disciplinary collaboration between pure mathematics, applied mathematics, and physics, with rewarding applications in plasma and fluid engineering, as well as ocean and atmospheric science.

por.por_cntn:
The PI has successfully completed most of the projects proposed. The proposal was split in three sections: Section A) pertained to the effect of the geometry of the domain on the long-time behavior of nonlinear dispersive PDE. In this direction, the PI (in collaboration with B. Pausader, N. Tzvetkov, and N. Visciglia) studies the cubic nonlinear Schrodinger equation on the cylindrical domain RxT^d and proved the existence of solutions exhibiting infinite growth of Sobolev norms. This is the first result on infinite energy cascades for NLS, or for that matter any natural nonlinear dispersive PDE.

Section B) pertained to asymptotic behavior on R^d in situations when dispersion is not too strong. Such problems are of interest in several areas of physics like general relativity and various field theories (asymptotic stability of topological solitons and kinks). In this direction, the PI (in collaboration with P. Germain and S. Walsh), showed scattering for the quadratic Schrodinger equation with an external potential. This required developing new tools in harmonic analysis, namely Coifmann-Meyer type estimates in the presence of a potential.

Section C) pertained to questions related to wave turbulence. The PI proposed a novel approach to deriving effective equations for the nonlinear Schrodinger equation by performing some of the limits taken in wave turbulence closures. The PI (in a work with E. Faou and P. Germain, and three later works with L. Thomann) succeeded in executing this proposed project. The result was a new equation that describes the effective dynamics of NLS on a box of size L on very long time scales. This newly derived equation is very special, in the sense that it enjoys many interesting symmetries, like invariance under the Fourier transform and the harmonic oscillator eigenspaces. This research direction is a crucial step towards rigorously justifying the main equations of wave turbulence, and features a very nice interplay between PDE, harmonic analysis, and analytic number theory.

The P.I. presented his work in talks and mini-courses at international conferences (around 10 per year). He also had successful interactions with physicists working on wave turbulence at two international conferences (Fields Institute 2013, and Jahanes Kappler University 2014), and at his home universities (NYU then GeorgiaTech). In Spring 2015, he taught a special topics course on dispersive PDE at GeorgiaTech, and started the “Working PDE seminar" aimed at introducing graduate students to various research topics in PDE. Results were established under these proposals  through international collaborations between the US, Australia, France, and Italy. ?
